A hemangioma arising from the mucous membranes.
A myxoma arising from the endocardium.

Pericarditis caused by the infiltration of the pericardium by a malignant neoplasm.  The diagnosis is based on the cytological examination of pericardial fluid or the histologic examination of pericardial tissue.
An aggressive malignant smooth muscle neoplasm, occurring in adults.  It is characterized by a proliferation of neoplastic spindle cells.
A neuroblastoma confined to a specific anatomic region without evidence of dissemination.
Wilms tumor that is found in one kidney and can be completely removed with surgery. (National Wilms Tumor Study Group Staging System)

Wilms tumor that is found in the kidney and in the fat, soft tissue, or blood vessels near the kidney. It may have spread to the renal sinus. The renal sinus is the part of the kidney where blood and fluid enter and exit the organ. The tumor can be completely removed with surgery. (National Wilms Tumor Study Group Staging System)

Wilms tumor that is found in areas near the kidney and cannot be completely removed with surgery. The tumor may have spread to nearby organs and blood vessels or throughout the abdomen and to nearby lymph nodes. Lymph nodes are tiny, bean-shaped organs that help fight infection. Stage III cancer has not spread outside the abdomen. (National Wilms Tumor Study Group Staging System)
Wilms tumor that has spread to other more distant organs, such as the lungs, liver, bones, and brain, or to lymph nodes outside the abdomen (National Wilms Tumor Study Group Staging System)
Wilms tumor that affects both kidneys at the same time. The tumor in each kidney is staged separately (National Wilms Tumor Study Group Staging System)

mondo_label: limited stage lung small cell carcinoma
original_label: Limited Stage Lung Small Cell Carcinoma
definition: Small cell lung carcinoma which is confined to one hemi-thorax and the regional lymph nodes.

Lymphomatoid granulomatosis characterized by the presence of a polymorphous lymphoid infiltrate without cytologic atypia. Large lymphocytes are absent or rare. By in situ hybridization, EBV-positive cells are infrequently seen.

Lymphomatoid granulomatosis characterized by the presence of occasional large lymphoid cells or immunoblasts in a polymorphous background. Necrosis is more commonly seen as compared to grade I lymphomatoid granulomatosis. By in situ hybridization, EBV-positive cells are readily seen.

mondo_label: breast ductal carcinoma in situ, high grade
original_label: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, High Grade
definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with severe dysplasia and the formation of micropapillary, cribriform, or solid patterns. The nuclei show marked pleomorphism and have prominent nucleoli. Mitotic activity is usually present. There is comedo-type of necrosis present in the ducts. The necrotic debris is surrounded by pleomorphic malignant cells.

mondo_label: breast paget disease with invasive ductal carcinoma
original_label: Breast Paget Disease with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
definition: Paget disease involving the skin overlying the mammary gland, accompanied by invasive ductal breast carcinoma.

mondo_label: childhood acute promyelocytic leukemia with t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.2); pml-rara
original_label: Childhood Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia with t(15;17)(q24.1;q21.2); PML-RARA
definition: An acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML-RARA fusion occurring in children.
An adenocarcinoma that arises from the common bile duct distal to the insertion of the cystic duct.
A rare condition characterized by the development of a carcinoma in a pre-existing craniopharyngioma.

mondo_label: testicular mixed embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor
original_label: Testicular Mixed Embryonal Carcinoma and Yolk Sac Tumor
definition: A malignant non-seminomatous germ cell tumor arising from the testis.  It is characterized by a mixture of embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac morphologic elements.  Patients may present with painless or painful testicular swelling.

mondo_label: testicular mixed yolk sac tumor and teratoma
original_label: Testicular Mixed Yolk Sac Tumor and Teratoma
definition: A malignant non-seminomatous germ cell tumor arising from the testis.  It is characterized by a mixture of yolk sac and teratomatous morphologic elements.  Patients may present with painless or painful testicular swelling.

mondo_label: testicular mixed yolk sac tumor and teratoma with seminoma
original_label: Testicular Mixed Yolk Sac Tumor and Teratoma with Seminoma
definition: A malignant germ cell tumor arising from the testis.  It is characterized by a mixture of yolk sac, teratomatous, and seminomatous morphologic elements.  Patients may present with painless or painful testicular swelling.

A usually malignant, somatostatin producing neuroendocrine tumor, arising from the delta cells of the pancreas.  It may or may not be associated with inappropriate secretion of somatostatin and an associated clinical syndrome.

A salivary gland carcinoma with low-grade histopathologic features.  It includes the salivary gland polymorphous low grade adenocarcinoma, salivary gland low grade cribriform cystadenocarcinoma, and low grade salivary gland mucoepidermoid carcinoma.  It usually follows a non-aggressive clinical course.
A basal cell carcinoma arising from the lip.

mondo_label: salivary gland intermediate grade mucoepidermoid carcinoma
original_label: Salivary Gland Intermediate Grade Mucoepidermoid Carcinoma
definition: A salivary gland mucoepidermoid carcinoma with intermediate-grade histopathologic features.

A usually aggressive salivary gland carcinoma with high-grade histopathologic features.  It includes the salivary duct carcinoma, salivary gland oncocytic carcinoma, and high grade salivary gland mucoepidermoid carcinoma.

An adenocarcinoma arising from the salivary gland.  It includes the salivary gland polymorphous low grade adenocarcinoma, salivary gland oncocytic carcinoma, salivary gland mucinous adenocarcinoma, salivary gland low grade cribriform cystadenocarcinoma, salivary gland cystadenocarcinoma, salivary gland basal cell adenocarcinoma, salivary gland acinic cell carcinoma, salivary duct carcinoma, and salivary gland adenocarcinoma not otherwise specified.

mondo_label: salivary gland poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
original_label: Salivary Gland Poorly Differentiated Squamous Cell Carcinoma
definition: A poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma arising from the salivary gland.
A salivary gland carcinoma characterized by the presence of undifferentiated, anaplastic malignant epithelial cells.

mondo_label: diffuse large b-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
original_label: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: A term referring to a group of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas which are biologically heterogeneous. These lymphomas have a centroblastic, immunoblastic, or anaplastic morphology.

mondo_label: diffuse large b-cell lymphoma associated with chronic inflammation
original_label: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma Associated with Chronic Inflammation
definition: A diffuse large B-cell lymphoma arising in body cavities or narrow spaces of long standing chronic inflammation.  The classic example is the pyothorax-associated lymphoma that arises in the pleural cavity of patients with a history of long standing pyothorax.

mondo_label: progressive hairy cell leukemia initial treatment
original_label: Progressive Hairy Cell Leukemia Initial Treatment
definition: A hairy cell leukemia requiring initial treatment because of the presence of signs of progression.  Signs of progression include cytopenia (especially if symptomatic), increasing splenomegaly, and infectious complications.  Therapy is not necessary if the patients are asymptomatic and the blood counts are maintained in an acceptable range.

mondo_label: high grade b-cell lymphoma, not otherwise specified
original_label: High Grade B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: High-grade B-cell lymphoma with blastoid features or features between diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma that lacks MYC, BCL2, and BCL6 gene rearrangements.

A nodal follicular lymphoma with favorable prognosis. It lacks BCL-2 rearrangement and 14;18 translocation. Nearly all cases are localized. It is usually seen in the pediatric population but similar lymphomas may occur in adults.

A monoclonal expansion of B-lymphocytes with or without the characteristic immunophenotype of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. It precedes virtually all cases of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma.

mondo_label: b lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, not otherwise specified
original_label: B Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: B-lymphoblastic leukemias/lymphomas characterized by the absence of recurrent genetic abnormalities.

mondo_label: b lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with t(1;19)(q23;p13.3); tcf3-pbx1
original_label: B Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma with t(1;19)(q23;p13.3); TCF3-PBX1
definition: A precursor lymphoid neoplasm which is composed of B-lymphoblasts and carries a translocation between the E2A gene on chromosome 19 and the PBX1 gene on chromosome 1.
A pheochromocytoma that has not spread to other regions.

mondo_label: stage i ovarian germ cell tumor ajcc v6 and v7
original_label: Stage I Ovarian Germ Cell Tumor AJCC v6 and v7
definition: Stage I includes: (T1, N0, M0). T1: Tumor limited to ovaries (one or both).  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

mondo_label: stage ii ovarian germ cell tumor ajcc v6 and v7
original_label: Stage II Ovarian Germ Cell Tumor AJCC v6 and v7
definition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: stage iii ovarian germ cell tumor ajcc v6 and v7
original_label: Stage III Ovarian Germ Cell Tumor AJCC v6 and v7
definition: Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: stage iv ovarian germ cell tumor ajcc v6 and v7
original_label: Stage IV Ovarian Germ Cell Tumor AJCC v6 and v7
definition: Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: regional renal pelvis and ureter urothelial carcinoma
original_label: Regional Renal Pelvis and Ureter Urothelial Carcinoma
definition: Urothelial carcinoma of the renal pelvis or ureter that has spread to adjacent tissues and/or regional lymph nodes but not to distant anatomic sites.
A verrucous carcinoma of the oral cavity that arises from the buccal mucosa.

A very rare dendritic cell sarcoma affecting the lymph nodes, spleen, and soft tissues. Morphologically it is similar to the interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma or follicular dendritic cell sarcoma. The tumor cells are positive for cytokeratin and CD68.

Juvenile xanthogranuloma disseminated to extracutaneous sites including mucosal surfaces, lung, central nervous system, pituitary, lymph nodes, eye, liver, and bone marrow. It is characterized by the presence of lipid-laden, foamy histiocytes and Touton-type giant cells forming nodules in the affected anatomic sites.
An adenoid cystic carcinoma arising from the minor salivary glands in the oral cavity.

A rare mixed phenotype acute leukemia in which the blasts express B-lymphoid and myeloid lineage markers but are negative for KMT2A rearrangement and t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) translocation. The prognosis is usually unfavorable.

A rare mixed phenotype acute leukemia in which the blasts express T-lymphoid and myeloid lineage markers but are negative for KMT2A rearrangement and t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) translocation. The prognosis is usually unfavorable.
A precursor lymphoid neoplasm that expresses CD56 and immature T-cell markers, lacks B-lymphoid and myeloid markers, and has immunoglobulin and T-cell receptor genes in the germline configuration.

A myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm arising as a result of the mutagenic effect of chemotherapy agents and/or radiation that are used for the treatment of neoplastic or non-neoplastic disorders.

mondo_label: acute myeloid leukemia with myelodysplasia-related gene mutations
original_label: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with Myelodysplasia-Related Gene Mutations
definition: A group of acute myeloid leukemias characterized by the presence of gene mutations that are associated with myelodysplasia.
A primary myelodysplastic syndrome not associated with prior radiation or chemotherapy treatment.
An astrocytoma occurring in adults that is characterized by the presence of high mitotic activity, cytologic atypia, and architectural distortion.
A myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by the presence of at least 10% dysplastic neutrophils in the bone marrow or the peripheral blood.
A myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by the presence of at least 10% dysplastic megakaryocytes, found within at least 30 megakaryocytes examined in the bone marrow.

mondo_label: myelodysplastic syndrome with excess blasts and fibrosis
original_label: Myelodysplastic Syndrome with Excess Blasts and Fibrosis
definition: Myelodysplastic syndrome with excess blasts associated with significant reticulin fibrosis of the bone marrow.

mondo_label: myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm with ring sideroblasts and thrombocytosis, not otherwise specified
original_label: Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative Neoplasm with Ring Sideroblasts and Thrombocytosis, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: A myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by marked thrombocytosis, anemia, erythroid lineage dysplasia, presence or absence of multilineage dysplasia, 15% or more ring sideroblasts, blasts less than 5% in bone marrow and less than 1% in peripheral blood, absence of BCR/ABL fusion, absence of SF3B1 mutation, absence of genetic abnormalities associated with myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with eosinophilia and tyrosine kinase gene fusions, and no history of other myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms or myeloproliferative neoplasms and myelodysplastic syndromes.
A cholangiocarcinoma occurring in adults.
A benign melanocytic nevus surrounded by eczematous changes.
An oncocytoma with cystic degenerative changes.
An extraskeletal osteosarcoma affecting the duodenum.
A pleomorphic adenoma with increased cellularity.
A precancerous neoplastic process that affects the squamous, glandular, or transitional cell epithelium without evidence of invasion. It is characterized by the presence of mild epithelial dysplasia.
A lymphangioma affecting several anatomic sites.
A benign, intermediate, or malignant mesenchymal neoplasm composed of fibrohistiocytic cells, spindle fibroblastic cells, and histiocytes, in a storiform pattern.

A neoplasm that arises from the supraglottis and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.
A non-metastasizing neoplasm that arises from the Bartholin gland. Representative examples include adenoma and adenomyoma.
A diffuse malignant neoplasm that arises from mesothelial cells, usually in the pleura or peritoneum. Histologic variants include biphasic, epithelioid, sarcomatoid, and desmoplastic mesothelioma.
A benign mesenchymoma arising from the kidney.
A rare neurofibroma with an infiltrative growth pattern.  It involves the skin and subcutaneous tissue and grows in a plaque-like fashion.  Malignant transformation is rare.
An astroblastoma, MN1-altered, characterized by the presence of high mitotic activity, cytologic atypia, and architectural distortion.
A disorder affecting the lungs due to asbestos exposure. Examples include asbestosis and lung carcinoma.
A cavernous hemangioma arising from the central nervous system.
Cancer that has spread beyond the layer of tissue in which it developed and is growing into surrounding, healthy tissues.
A carcinoma that does not respond to treatment.
A malignant neoplasm that has spread from its original site of growth to nearby tissues or lymph nodes.

A neoplasm that arises from the respiratory system and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.

mondo_label: metastatic malignant neoplasm in the nervous system
original_label: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Nervous System
definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm to the nervous system.  This may be from a primary nervous system malignant neoplasm, or from a malignant neoplasm at a distant site.

mondo_label: metastatic malignant neoplasm in the retina
original_label: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Retina
definition: A malignant neoplasm that has spread to the retina from another anatomic site.

mondo_label: metastatic malignant neoplasm of unknown primary
original_label: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm of Unknown Primary
definition: The spread of a malignant neoplasm from an unknown primary to another region remote from the primary site.
A carcinoma that arises from the cervix and invades into the stromal tissue.
A polyp with severe dysplastic features.
A usually terminal event in the clinical course of lymphomas.  The term indicates the presence of atypical, clonal (malignant) lymphocytes (lymphoma cells) in the peripheral blood.
A carcinoma of the hypopharynx that arises from the postcricoid region.
An anaplastic (malignant) meningioma involving the spinal meninges.

A malignant neoplasm that affects the liver parenchyma, bile ducts, and gallbladder.  Representative examples include hepatocellular carcinoma, intrahepatic and extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, and gallbladder carcinoma.

mondo_label: metastatic malignant neoplasm in the adrenal gland
original_label: Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Adrenal Gland
definition: A malignant tumor that has spread to the adrenal gland from an adjacent or distant anatomic site.  The majority of cases are metastatic carcinomas, and less frequently lymphomas.

Ann Arbor Classification: Stage I: Involvement of a single lymph node region (I); or localized involvement of a single extralymphatic organ or site in the absence of any lymph node involvement (IE) (Rare in Hodgkin lymphoma).

Ann Arbor Classification: Stage II: Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II); or localized involvement of a single extralymphatic organ or site in a with regional lymph node involvement with or without involvement of other lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE).

Ann Arbor Classification: Stage III: Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which also may be accompanied by extralymphatic extension in association with adjacent lymph node involvement (IIIE) or by involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or both (IIIE,S).

Ann Arbor Classification: Stage IV: Diffuse or disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs, with or without associated lymph node involvement; or isolated extralymphatic organ involvement in the absence of adjacent regional lymph node involvement, but in conjunction with disease in distant site(s); or any involvement of the liver or bone marrow, or nodular involvement of the lungs(s).
A malignant hemangiopericytoma which has spread to another anatomical site.
A rare malignant mesenchymal neoplasm that is believed to have its origin in smooth muscle derived pericytes without evidence of metastases.
Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0. T1: Tumor limited to ovaries (one or both). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
Stage I carcinoma of the pharynx according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th, 7th, and 8th editions.
Stage II carcinoma of the pharynx according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th, 7th, and 8th editions.
Stage III carcinoma of the pharynx according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th, 7th, and 8th editions.
Stage IV carcinoma of the pharynx according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th, 7th, and 8th editions.

An uncommon type of lymphoma.  It constitutes approximately 10% of cases of lymphoblastic lymphoma.  Approximately 75% of cases reported in a literature review involved patients who were less than 18 years of age.  The most commonly affected sites are the skin, bone, soft tissue, and lymph nodes.  It has a high remission rate with a median survival of approximately 60 months.  (WHO, 2001)
An embryonal carcinoma that develops as a primary tumor in an anatomic site other than the testis or ovary.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder which occurs during infancy, childhood, or adolescence.

The most common gastric polyp in the Western hemisphere.  The lesion consists of a localized hyperplasia of the deep epithelial compartment of the oxyntic mucosa, with variable degrees of cystic dilatation.  Malignant transformation is the exception.  (WHO, 2000)
A benign or malignant neoplasm involving the oral cavity and/or the lips.

A group of malignant mast cell disorders including aggressive systemic mastocytosis, mast cell leukemia, mast cell sarcoma, and systemic mastocytosis with an associated myeloid neoplasm. Individuals with advanced systemic mastocytosis have a reduced life expectancy, with median survival measured in months to years.

A neoplasm that arises from the adrenal cortex and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.

mondo_label: acute myelomonocytic leukemia with abnormal eosinophils
original_label: Acute Myelomonocytic Leukemia with Abnormal Eosinophils
definition: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia characterized by the presence of abnormal bone marrow eosinophils. It is associated with inv(16)(p13.1;q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22). It has a favorable prognosis.

Grading of sarcomas according to the French Federation of Cancer Centers Sarcoma Group (FNCLCC). This sarcoma grading system is based on three factors: differentiation, mitotic count, and tumor necrosis. The scores for each factor are added to determine the grade (1 to 3) for the sarcoma.
A low-grade chondrosarcoma characterized by the presence of moderate cellularity, hyperchromatic and plump nuclei of uniform size, and occasional binucleated cells.  Mitotic figures are absent.

mondo_label: renal cell cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Renal Cell Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of renal cell cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: bladder cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Bladder Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of bladder cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: vulvar cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Vulvar Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of vulvar carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: vaginal cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Vaginal Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of vaginal cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.
An angiosarcoma occurring in the adult population.

mondo_label: extensive stage lung small cell carcinoma
original_label: Extensive Stage Lung Small Cell Carcinoma
definition: Small cell lung carcinoma which has spread beyond one hemi-thorax and the regional lymph nodes.

mondo_label: cervical cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Cervical Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of cervical cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: uterine corpus cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Uterine Corpus Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of uterine corpus cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: fallopian tube cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Fallopian Tube Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of fallopian tube carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: esophageal cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Esophageal Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of esophageal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: gastric cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Gastric Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage

mondo_label: colorectal cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Colorectal Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of colorectal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: hepatocellular carcinoma by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Hepatocellular Carcinoma by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of hepatocellular carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: gallbladder cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Gallbladder Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of gallbladder cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: breast cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Breast Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of breast cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: cutaneous melanoma by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Cutaneous Melanoma by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of cutaneous melanoma, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v6 classification system.

mondo_label: lung cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Lung Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of lung carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: penile cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Penile Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of penile carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: prostate cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Prostate Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of prostate carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: pharyngeal carcinoma by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Pharyngeal Carcinoma by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of pharyngeal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: laryngeal cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Laryngeal Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of laryngeal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: sinonasal cancer by ajcc v6 stage
original_label: Sinonasal Cancer by AJCC v6 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of nasal cavity and paranasal sinus carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition.

mondo_label: kaposi sarcoma related to immunosuppressive treatment
original_label: Kaposi Sarcoma Related to Immunosuppressive Treatment
definition: A Kaposi sarcoma that develops after immunosuppressive treatment.

mondo_label: renal cell cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Renal Cell Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of renal cell cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: bladder cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Bladder Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of bladder cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: vulvar cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Vulvar Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of vulvar carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: vaginal cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Vaginal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of vaginal cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: cervical cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Cervical Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of cervical cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: uterine corpus cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Uterine Corpus Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of uterine corpus cancer (carcinoma or carcinosarcoma) according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: fallopian tube cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Fallopian Tube Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of fallopian tube carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: esophageal cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Esophageal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of esophageal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: gastric cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Gastric Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of gastric carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: colorectal cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Colorectal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of colorectal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: hepatocellular carcinoma by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Hepatocellular Carcinoma by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of hepatocellular carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: gallbladder cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Gallbladder Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of gallbladder cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: breast cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Breast Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of breast cancer according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: cutaneous melanoma by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Cutaneous Melanoma by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of cutaneous melanoma, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.

mondo_label: lung cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Lung Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of lung carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: prostate cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Prostate Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of prostate carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: penile cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Penile Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of penile carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: pharyngeal carcinoma by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Pharyngeal Carcinoma by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of pharyngeal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: sinonasal cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Sinonasal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of nasal cavity and paranasal sinus carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: laryngeal cancer by ajcc v7 stage
original_label: Laryngeal Cancer by AJCC v7 Stage
definition: A term that refers to the staging of laryngeal carcinoma according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer, 7th edition.

mondo_label: chronic myeloid leukemia, philadelphia chromosome positive, bcr-abl1 positive
original_label: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia, Philadelphia Chromosome Positive, BCR-ABL1 Positive
definition: A chronic myeloid leukemia characterized by the t(9;22)(q34;q11) chromosomal translocation, resulting in the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome and the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.
An aggressive malignant mesenchymal neoplasm arising from skeletal muscle in adults.

mondo_label: invasive breast carcinoma of no special type with predominant intraductal component
original_label: Invasive Breast Carcinoma of No Special Type with Predominant Intraductal Component
definition: An invasive breast carcinoma of no special type characterized by the presence of a predominant ductal carcinoma in situ component and a minor component of invasive carcinoma.

mondo_label: invasive breast lobular carcinoma with predominant in situ component
original_label: Invasive Breast Lobular Carcinoma with Predominant In Situ Component
definition: A breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of a predominant lobular carcinoma in situ component and a minor component of invasive carcinoma.
An acute myeloid leukemia occurring in adults.

mondo_label: testicular mixed embryonal carcinoma and yolk sac tumor with seminoma
original_label: Testicular Mixed Embryonal Carcinoma and Yolk Sac Tumor with Seminoma
definition: A malignant germ cell tumor arising from the testis.  It is characterized by a mixture of embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac, and seminomatous morphologic elements.  Patients may present with painless or painful testicular swelling.

mondo_label: good prognosis metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor
original_label: Good Prognosis Metastatic Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
definition: Metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor in which risk factors are absent.

mondo_label: poor prognosis metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor
original_label: Poor Prognosis Metastatic Gestational Trophoblastic Tumor
definition: Metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor in which risk factors are present.
A benign schwannoma occurring in the eye.

mondo_label: esophageal malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor
original_label: Esophageal Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor
definition: A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor that affects the esophageal wall.

mondo_label: intraocular malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor
original_label: Intraocular Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor
definition: A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor that occurs in the intraocular area.
A malignant neoplasm that arises from a site other than the bone marrow and lymphoid tissue.
A rare malignant mesenchymal neoplasm, believed to have its origin in smooth muscle derived pericytes, which has recurred after treatment.
The occurrence of multiple and independent glioblastomas that are unrelated to inherited neoplastic syndromes.
A rare, WHO grade II or III infiltrating astrocytoma characterized by the presence of sharply demarcated foci, composed of a neuropil-like matrix.
A medulloblastoma characterized by marked nuclear pleomorphism, and high mitotic activity.

mondo_label: malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor with mesenchymal differentiation
original_label: Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumor with Mesenchymal Differentiation
definition: A malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor characterized by the presence of mesenchymal differentiation.  Representative example is the malignant Triton tumor which contains a rhabdomyosarcomatous component.

Mature T and NK neoplasms predominantly affecting the skin and the peripheral blood.  Peripheral blood involvement by abnormal T-cells (cerebriform cells) is a late manifestation of mycosis fungoides, whereas it is the presenting finding in Sezary syndrome.
A malignant neoplasm that has spread extensively to other anatomic sites or is no longer responding to treatment.
A diffuse subtype of classic Hodgkin lymphoma which is rich in Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells and/or depleted in non-neoplastic lymphocytes. (WHO, 2008)

mondo_label: central nervous system histiocytic and dendritic cell neoplasm
original_label: Central Nervous System Histiocytic and Dendritic Cell Neoplasm
definition: A neoplasm that originates from histiocytes and accessory cells and affects the central nervous system.  It is usually associated with the presence of identical tumors outside the central nervous system.  Representative examples include Langerhans cell histiocytosis, histiocytic sarcoma, and follicular dendritic cell sarcoma.
An aggressive malignant mesothelioma that arises from the peritoneum.  Patients usually present with abdominal pain and ascites.

mondo_label: combined lung small cell carcinoma and lung adenocarcinoma
original_label: Combined Lung Small Cell Carcinoma and Lung Adenocarcinoma
definition: A lung carcinoma characterized by a combination of small cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma.
A malignant hemangiopericytoma with well-differentiated morphological features.

mondo_label: childhood hematopoietic and lymphoid cell neoplasm
original_label: Childhood Hematopoietic and Lymphoid Cell Neoplasm
definition: A neoplasm of hematopoietic and lymphoid cell origin that occurs during childhood. Representative examples include acute leukemias and lymphomas.
A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with more than 95% glandular formation.
A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with 50-95% glandular formation.
A colorectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant cellular infiltrate with less than 50% glandular formation.

A very rare, WHO grade 1 neoplasm of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by the presence of spindle cells with eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm forming fascicles.  Electron microscopic studies demonstrate the accumulation of intracytoplasmic mitochondria and lack of secretory granules.  Immunohistochemical studies are negative for pituitary hormones.  Patients may present with pituitary hypofunction, visual disturbances, headache, nausea and vomiting.  The clinical course is usually benign.

mondo_label: breast ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate grade
original_label: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Intermediate Grade
definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of monomorphic neoplastic cells that form cribriform, micropapillary, or solid patterns. Intraluminal necrosis is present in some ducts. Ducts that contain neoplastic cells with occasional nucleoli and coarse chromatin may also be present.

mondo_label: breast ductal carcinoma in situ, low grade
original_label: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Low Grade
definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of small, monomorphic neoplastic cells that form cribriform, micropapillary, or solid patterns. The nuclei are uniform and mitotic figures are rare.
A neoplasm of low malignant potential arising from the ovary. It is characterized by the presence of neoplastic atypical urothelial-type cells in a fibrotic stroma without evidence of invasion.
An anaplastic large cell lymphoma that is not confined to a single anatomic site and involves multiple nodal and/or extranodal sites.
Infiltration of the meninges by an acute or chronic leukemia.
Involvement of the meninges by Hodgkin or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
A breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of multiple cancerous tumors that originate from the same clone and are usually located in the same quadrant of the breast.
A breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of multiple cancerous tumors that originate from different clones and are usually located in different quadrants of the breast.
Breast carcinoma that has not spread beyond the breast and the axillary lymph nodes.
Malignant neoplasms occurring in families at a rate greater than that expected by chance and caused by germline mutations in a specific gene.

mondo_label: stage i borderline ovarian surface epithelial-stromal tumor
original_label: Stage I Borderline Ovarian Surface Epithelial-Stromal Tumor
definition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0. T1: Tumor limited to ovaries (one or both).  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: stage ii borderline ovarian surface epithelial-stromal tumor
original_label: Stage II Borderline Ovarian Surface Epithelial-Stromal Tumor
definition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0.  T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: stage iii borderline ovarian surface epithelial-stromal tumor
original_label: Stage III Borderline Ovarian Surface Epithelial-Stromal Tumor
definition: Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0.  T3: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

mondo_label: stage iv borderline ovarian surface epithelial-stromal tumor
original_label: Stage IV Borderline Ovarian Surface Epithelial-Stromal Tumor
definition: Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)
A usually benign neoplasm that arises from the sun-exposed skin, eye, and meninges. It is composed of spindle and/or epithelioid melanocytes and melanophages. It rarely progresses to melanoma.
A benign extrauterine tumor composed of mature adipocytes and smooth muscle cells.
A liposarcoma that arises from the thymus gland.  It is characterized by the presence of a liposarcomatous malignant infiltrate that entraps lobules of thymic tissue.
A thymoma that arises in the cervical region and is not connected with the thymus gland.

A neoplastic lesion that shows morphologic evidence of invasion into the lamina propria or muscularis mucosa.  There is no evidence of invasion into the submucosa.  Evidence of invasion may refer to stromal invasion by single cells or clusters of cells, presence of atypical and complex glandular architectural patterns beyond those that are present in normal mucosa, desmoplasia, and/or vascular invasion.
A pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of duct-like structures and medium-sized malignant glandular structures.
A pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of medium-sized duct-like structures and small malignant tubular glandular structures.
A pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of small and irregular malignant glandular structures, solid sheets of malignant cells, and single malignant cells.
A carcinoma that arises from the pancreas showing either extensive mucin accumulation and acinar neoplastic cells or a mixture of columnar or signet-ring cells and acinar neoplastic cells.

mondo_label: pancreatic mixed ductal adenocarcinoma-acinar carcinoma-neuroendocrine carcinoma
original_label: Pancreatic Mixed Ductal Adenocarcinoma-Acinar Carcinoma-Neuroendocrine Carcinoma
definition: A very rare carcinoma that arises from the pancreas and is composed of ductal adenocarcinoma, acinar carcinoma, and neuroendocrine carcinoma components.
A rare adenocarcinoma that arises from the pancreas.  It is characterized by marked hepatocellular differentiation.

A pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma characterized by poor differentiation and a prominent syncytial growth pattern.  The prognosis is more favorable compared to conventional pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.

A benign, non-metastasizing, usually cystic epithelial neoplasm arising from the exocrine pancreas.  It is composed of glycogen-rich epithelial cells which produce a watery fluid.  Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.

A group of cystic or mass-forming epithelial neoplasms that arise from the exocrine pancreas, exhibit ductal differentiation, and grow mostly within the pancreatic ducts.  This group includes the pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms and the pancreatic intraductal tubulopapillary neoplasms.

mondo_label: pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm, gastric-type
original_label: Pancreatic Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm, Gastric-Type
definition: A pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelial cells that are similar to gastric foveolar epithelial cells.

mondo_label: pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm, intestinal-type
original_label: Pancreatic Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm, Intestinal-Type
definition: A pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelial cells that form tall papillae, similar to those that are present in colonic villous adenomas.

mondo_label: pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm, pancreatobiliary-type
original_label: Pancreatic Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasm, Pancreatobiliary-Type
definition: A pancreatic intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelial cells that form thin-branching papillae and exhibit high grade dysplasia.
A low grade well differentiated neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the pancreas. It is characterized by the absence of a hormone-related clinical syndrome.

A usually malignant pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor producing vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP).  It is associated with watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria.  One third of cases are metastatic at the time of diagnosis.

An esophageal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of a spindle-cell carcinomatous component.  Crossly it has a polypoid appearance and usually arises from the middle or lower third of the esophagus.

mondo_label: esophageal well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
original_label: Esophageal Well Differentiated Squamous Cell Carcinoma
definition: An esophageal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of prominent keratinization and low mitotic activity.

mondo_label: esophageal moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
original_label: Esophageal Moderately Differentiated Squamous Cell Carcinoma
definition: An esophageal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of variable morphologic characteristics that include areas of prominent and poor keratinization.

mondo_label: esophageal poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma
original_label: Esophageal Poorly Differentiated Squamous Cell Carcinoma
definition: An esophageal squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of basal-like malignant squamous cells that form nests, often associated with central necrosis.

A carcinoma that arises from the esophagus and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.
A synovial sarcoma that affects the esophageal wall.
A neoplastic polyp that arises from the stomach.  It is characterized by the presence of gastric epithelial differentiation.  It includes pyloric gland adenomas and foveolar-type adenomas.

A carcinoma that arises from the stomach and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.
A rare schwannoma that arises from the stomach.  It follows a benign clinical course.

mondo_label: ampulla of vater pancreatobiliary type adenocarcinoma
original_label: Ampulla of Vater Pancreatobiliary Type Adenocarcinoma
definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma that arises from the ampulla of Vater. It is characterized by the presence of malignant cells that resemble the malignant cells of the pancreatic ductal or extrahepatic bile duct carcinomas.

A very rare adenocarcinoma that arises from the ampulla of Vater.  It is usually of the intestinal type and is characterized by the presence of malignant polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm resembling hepatocytes.

A neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the ampulla of Vater and periampullary region. It includes neuroendocrine tumors (well-differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms) and neuroendocrine carcinomas (poorly differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms).

mondo_label: ampulla of vater mixed adenoneuroendocrine carcinoma
original_label: Ampulla of Vater Mixed Adenoneuroendocrine Carcinoma
definition: A carcinoma that arises from the ampulla of Vater and the periampullary region. It is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.
A well differentiated, low, intermediate, or high grade neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the small or large intestine.

A carcinoma that arises from the small intestine and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.

A neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the colon or rectum. It includes neuroendocrine tumors (well-differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms) and neuroendocrine carcinomas (poorly differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms).

A carcinoma that arises from the colon or rectum and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.

A well differentiated, intermediate grade neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the digestive system. The mitotic count is 2-20 per 10 HPF and/or the Ki67 index is 3 to 20 percent.
Polyps that arises from the large intestine and the appendix. They are characterized by the presence of serrated glands and the absence of generalized dysplasia.

mondo_label: appendix enterochromaffin cell serotonin-producing neuroendocrine tumor
original_label: Appendix Enterochromaffin Cell Serotonin-Producing Neuroendocrine Tumor
definition: A well differentiated neuroendocrine tumor arising from the wall of the appendix.  It is characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells forming round solid nests and occasionally glandular structures.  The majority of the cases are asymptomatic, and they are found incidentally in appendectomy specimens.  The majority of the tumors are located in the distal end of the appendix and they are enterochromaffin-cell carcinoid tumors producing serotonin.  Most cases show morphologic evidence of appendiceal wall and lymphatic vessel invasion by tumor cells.  Despite the morphologic evidence of invasion, appendiceal carcinoid tumors only infrequently produce lymph node or distant metastases.
Polyps that arises from the rectum. They are characterized by the presence of serrated glands and the absence of generalized dysplasia.
A rare, invasive colon adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant infiltrate with serrated glandular architecture.
A rare, invasive rectal adenocarcinoma characterized by the presence of a malignant infiltrate with serrated glandular architecture.
A biphasic colorectal carcinoma with a spindle cell, sarcomatoid component.
A schwannoma that arises from the colon or rectum.  It may cause gastrointestinal bleeding and luminal obstruction.
A ganglioneuroma that arises from the colon or rectum.  It usually presents as a small mucosal polyp.

A granular cell tumor that arises from the colon or rectum and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.
A usually aggressive malignant epithelial neoplasm that arises from the anal canal.  It is composed of malignant cells which do not display evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation.

A carcinoma that arises from the anal canal.  It is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.

A benign epithelial neoplasm that arises from the anal canal.  It is characterized by a papillary growth pattern and a proliferation of neoplastic squamous cells without morphologic evidence of malignancy.

A benign neoplasm arising from the perianal sweat glands. It presents as a cystic nodular lesion and is characterized by the presence of cystic and papillary structures. The papillary structures contain connective tissue and are covered by two layers of epithelium.
A hepatocellular adenoma caused by inactivating mutations of the HNF1A gene.  It is characterized by the presence of lobulated contours, steatosis, and absence of inflammation or nuclear atypia.

A hepatocellular adenoma caused by activating mutations of beta-catenin.  It is characterized by the presence of nuclear atypia and absence of inflammation or steatosis.  There is an increased risk of malignant transformation.
A hepatocellular adenoma that occurs more often in women.  It is characterized by increased levels of inflammation-associated proteins.  It is usually associated with steatosis and obesity.
A hepatocellular adenoma without distinguished morphologic characteristics or known molecular abnormalities.

An extremely rare neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the liver. It includes neuroendocrine tumors (well-differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms) and neuroendocrine carcinomas (poorly differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms).
A rare type of hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by the presence of pleomorphic malignant cells that are intermixed with lymphocytes.

A hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant cells with mild atypia and an increased nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio forming thin trabecular patterns.  It is usually associated with small tumors and an early stage.

A hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm forming trabecular and pseudoglandular patterns.  It is usually associated with tumors that are larger than 3 cm in diameter.
A hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant pleomorphic cells forming solid patterns.

A rare carcinoma that arises from the liver.  The diagnosis is made by immunohistochemical studies.  Morphologic studies alone cannot establish the diagnosis of carcinoma or further subclassify the malignant tumor.
An intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma that arises from the small interlobular bile ducts.

mondo_label: bile duct intraductal papillary neoplasm with an associated invasive carcinoma
original_label: Bile Duct Intraductal Papillary Neoplasm with an Associated Invasive Carcinoma
definition: An intraductal papillary neoplasm that arises from the epithelium of the intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.
An adenoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.  It is characterized by the presence of tubular and papillary growth patterns.
A synovial sarcoma that affects the liver.

An aggressive carcinoma with a sarcomatous component that arises from the liver.  The sarcomatous component is clonally related to the more differentiated, carcinomatous component.  The prognosis is usually poor.

An epithelial, usually multiloculated neoplasm arising from the gallbladder. It occurs predominantly in females. Signs and symptoms include abdominal mass, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Morphologically, the cystic spaces are lined by columnar epithelium and contain mucinous or serous fluid.

A carcinoma that arises from the gallbladder and it is characterized by the presence of a sarcomatous component.  The sarcomatous component may contain osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, or rhabdomyosarcoma elements.
A rare variant of gallbladder adenocarcinoma.  It is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial infiltrate that resembles hepatocellular carcinoma.
A rare variant of gallbladder adenocarcinoma.  It is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial infiltrate with a cribriform growth pattern.

A well or moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that arises from the gallbladder.  It is the most common type of gallbladder carcinoma and is characterized by the presence of malignant tubular glands.  Intestinal differentiation may be present.

An unusual, well differentiated adenocarcinoma that arises from the gallbladder.  It is characterized by the presence of tall malignant columnar cells with mucin-containing cytoplasm and basally located nuclei.

A carcinoma that arises from the gallbladder and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.

A neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the gallbladder.  It does not show the morphologic characteristics of typical carcinoid tumors (neoplastic cells forming solid nests). In contrast, the tumor cells form small discrete tubules.

mondo_label: extrahepatic bile duct adenocarcinoma, biliary type
original_label: Extrahepatic Bile Duct Adenocarcinoma, Biliary Type
definition: A well or moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.  It is characterized by the presence of malignant tubular glands.

mondo_label: extrahepatic bile duct adenocarcinoma, gastric foveolar type
original_label: Extrahepatic Bile Duct Adenocarcinoma, Gastric Foveolar Type
definition: An unusual, well differentiated adenocarcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.  It is characterized by the presence of tall malignant columnar cells with mucin-containing cytoplasm and basally located nuclei.

mondo_label: extrahepatic bile duct adenocarcinoma, intestinal type
original_label: Extrahepatic Bile Duct Adenocarcinoma, Intestinal Type
definition: An adenocarcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts.  It is characterized by the presence of neoplastic tubular glands lined by columnar cells or neoplastic glands lined by goblet cells.
A carcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts and it is characterized by the presence of a sarcomatous component.

mondo_label: extrahepatic bile duct mucinous cystic neoplasm with an associated invasive carcinoma
original_label: Extrahepatic Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm with an Associated Invasive Carcinoma
definition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.

mondo_label: intrahepatic bile duct mucinous cystic neoplasm with an associated invasive carcinoma
original_label: Intrahepatic Bile Duct Mucinous Cystic Neoplasm with an Associated Invasive Carcinoma
definition: A mucinous cystic neoplasm that arises from the intrahepatic bile ducts and it is associated with an invasive carcinomatous component.
A lymphoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts, with the bulk of the disease located at this site.

A neoplasm with neuroendocrine differentiation that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts. It includes neuroendocrine tumors (well-differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms) and neuroendocrine carcinomas (poorly differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasms).

mondo_label: extrahepatic bile duct mixed adenoneuroendocrine carcinoma
original_label: Extrahepatic Bile Duct Mixed Adenoneuroendocrine Carcinoma
definition: A carcinoma that arises from the extrahepatic bile ducts and is characterized by the presence of a malignant glandular epithelial component and a malignant neuroendocrine component.  At least 30 percent of either component should be present for the diagnosis to be made.

mondo_label: invasive breast lobular carcinoma, alveolar variant
original_label: Invasive Breast Lobular Carcinoma, Alveolar Variant
definition: A grade I invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by the presence of round groups of neoplastic cells.

mondo_label: invasive breast lobular carcinoma, pleomorphic variant
original_label: Invasive Breast Lobular Carcinoma, Pleomorphic Variant
definition: A grade II invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells with large and atypical nuclei.

mondo_label: invasive breast lobular carcinoma, solid variant
original_label: Invasive Breast Lobular Carcinoma, Solid Variant
definition: A grade I invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells that form trabeculae and groups infiltrating collagen bundles.

mondo_label: invasive breast lobular carcinoma, tubulolobular variant
original_label: Invasive Breast Lobular Carcinoma, Tubulolobular Variant
definition: An invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by the presence of neoplastic cells forming small tubular structures.
A congenital mesoblastic nephroma characterized by the presence of classic and cellular areas.
Breast carcinoma that develops in the opposite breast of a patient with an already diagnosed primary breast carcinoma.
Melanoma that occurs in Oryzias latipes.
Melanoma that occurs in Xiphophorus.
A neoplastic condition occurring in a non-human organism; this includes neoplasms occurring in organisms used in research settings.

A benign ovarian epithelial tumor. It has been described in mice and rats and is rare in other animal species. Morphologically it is characterized by the presence of tubular structures and interstitial stroma.
A malignant ovarian epithelial tumor. It has been described in mice and rats and is characterized by marked pleomorphism, atypia, and an infiltrative growth pattern.

A squamous cell carcinoma that arises from the vagina and is characterized by the presence of polygonal squamous cells. Intercellular bridges and cytoplasmic keratinization may be present, but keratin pearls are absent.

mondo_label: lymphoproliferative disease associated with primary immune disorder
original_label: Lymphoproliferative Disease Associated with Primary Immune Disorder
definition: A lymphoid proliferation that arises in the setting of immune deficiency due to a primary immunodeficiency or immunoregulatory disorder. The primary immune disorders most frequently associated with lymphoproliferative disorders are ataxia-telangiectasia, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, common variable immunodeficiency, severe combined immunodeficiency, X-linked lymphoproliferative disease, Nijmegen breakage syndrome, hyper-IgM syndrome, and autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. (WHO 2017)
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the genitourinary system.
The reemergence of HIV-associated lymphoproliferative disorder after a period of remission.
HIV-associated lymphoproliferative disorder that is resistant to treatment.
A lymphoproliferative disorder that develops in an individual with HIV infection.

mondo_label: ebv-related lymphoproliferative disease with primary immunodeficiency
original_label: EBV-Related Lymphoproliferative Disease with Primary Immunodeficiency
definition: An EBV-related lymphoid proliferation that arises in the setting of immune deficiency due to a primary immunodeficiency or immunoregulatory disorder.

mondo_label: recurrent ebv-related lymphoproliferative disease with primary immunodeficiency
original_label: Recurrent EBV-Related Lymphoproliferative Disease with Primary Immunodeficiency
definition: The reemergence of EBV-associated lymphoproliferative disease with primary immunodeficiency after a period of remission.

mondo_label: refractory ebv-related lymphoproliferative disease with primary immunodeficiency
original_label: Refractory EBV-Related Lymphoproliferative Disease with Primary Immunodeficiency
definition: EBV-associated lymphoproliferative disease with primary immunodeficiency that is resistant to treatment.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the tonsils.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the soft tissue.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the connective and soft tissue.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the anatomic structures of the neck region.  This category includes disorders of the pharynx, larynx, thyroid gland, and parathyroid gland.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the peritoneum and/or retroperitoneum.

A precancerous lesion that arises from the female reproductive system. Representative examples include atypical endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia, and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia.
Any disease or disorder that is caused by the use of tobacco.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the sternum.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the structures of the chest wall.  Representative examples include infection, chest wall lipoma, and chest wall lymphoma.

A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the structures of the axilla.  Representative examples include axillary lymphadenitis, axillary lipoma, and metastatic carcinoma to the axillary lymph nodes.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder that affects the hematopoietic and lymphatic system.
A premalignant pathologic process that affects the lungs.  This category includes bronchial intraepithelial neoplasia and atypical adenomatous hyperplasia.
A non-neoplastic or neoplastic disorder which occurs during the neonatal period.

mondo_label: core binding factor acute myeloid leukemia
original_label: Core Binding Factor Acute Myeloid Leukemia
definition: Acute myeloid leukemia characterized by the presence of t(8;21)(q22;q22) or inv(16)(p13q22)/t(16;16)(p13;q22). These cytogenetic abnormalities result in disruption of the transcription factor CBF, which is a regulator of normal hematopoiesis.
An acute eosinophilic leukemia occurring in adults.

mondo_label: acute myeloid leukemia (megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1); rbm15-mkl1
original_label: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (Megakaryoblastic) with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1); RBM15-MKL1
definition: An acute myeloid leukemia associated with t(1;22)(p13.3;q13.1) resulting in the expression of RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein. It affects infants and children and usually shows megakaryocytic maturation.
An acute eosinophilic leukemia occurring in children.

mondo_label: acute myeloid leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22); cbfb-myh11
original_label: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with inv(16)(p13.1q22) or t(16;16)(p13.1;q22); CBFB-MYH11
definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with monocytic and granulocytic differentiation and the presence of a characteristically abnormal eosinophil component in the bone marrow.  This type of acute myeloid leukemia has a favorable prognosis.  (WHO, 2001)

mondo_label: acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1); runx1-runx1t1
original_label: Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with t(8;21)(q22; q22.1) giving rise to RUNX1/RUNX1T1 fusion transcript and showing maturation in the neutrophil lineage. The bone marrow and the peripheral blood show large myeloblasts with abundant basophilic cytoplasm, often containing azurophilic granules. This type of AML is associated with good response to chemotherapy and high complete remission rate.

An undifferentiated, high grade small round cell sarcoma affecting predominantly young adults. It is characterized by a recurrent translocation involving the CIC gene on chromosome 19 and either DUX4 gene on chromosome 4 or DUX4L gene on chromosome 10. The translocation results in either CIC-DUX4, t(4;19)(q35;q13) or CIC-DUX4L, t(10;19)(q26;q13) fusions.
Slowly progressive systemic mastocytosis with uncertain prognosis. It is characterized by organomegaly and absence of aggressive disease.

mondo_label: indolent clonal t-cell lymphoproliferative disorder of the gastrointestinal tract
original_label: Indolent Clonal T-Cell Lymphoproliferative Disorder of the Gastrointestinal Tract
definition: A clonal T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder that can involve the mucosa in all sites of the gastrointestinal tract, but is most common in the small intestine and colon. The lymphoid cells infiltrate the lamina propria but usually do not show invasion of the epithelium. The clinical course is indolent, but most patients do not respond to conventional chemotherapy. A subset of cases progress to a higher-grade T-cell lymphoma with spread beyond the gastrointestinal tract. (WHO 2017)
An extremely rare carcinoma that arises from the penis and is characterized by the presence of glandular and squamous components.
A mesenchymal neoplasm that arises from the seminal vesicle.

mondo_label: hepatocellular malignant neoplasm, not otherwise specified
original_label: Hepatocellular Malignant Neoplasm, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: A rare childhood malignant liver neoplasm with overlapping features of hepatoblastoma and hepatocellular carcinoma.

A rare neoplasm that arises from the epididymis and is characterized by the presence of a mixture of melanin-containing epithelial cells and smaller neuroblast-like cells. It usually occurs in infants and has a benign clinical course.

mondo_label: systemic mastocytosis with an associated germ cell tumor
original_label: Systemic Mastocytosis with an Associated Germ Cell Tumor
definition: A disorder characterized by systemic infiltration of internal organs by aggregates of neoplastic mast cells and the presence of a co-occurring germ cell tumor.
Breast adenocarcinoma that is positive for estrogen receptors.

mondo_label: childhood myelodysplastic syndrome with excess blasts
original_label: Childhood Myelodysplastic Syndrome with Excess Blasts
definition: Myelodysplastic syndrome with excess blasts that occurs during childhood.

mondo_label: childhood acute myeloid leukemia with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); mllt3-kmt2a
original_label: Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); MLLT3-KMT2A
definition: An acute myeloid leukemia with t(9;11)(p21.3;q23.3); MLLT3-KMT2A occurring in children.

mondo_label: lung small cell carcinoma neuroendocrine subtype
original_label: Lung Small Cell Carcinoma Neuroendocrine Subtype
definition: A header term that refers to the classification of lung small cell carcinoma based on the expression pattern of different neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin A, synaptophysin, neural cell adhesion molecule 1, and gastrin-releasing peptide.

mondo_label: lung small cell carcinoma molecular subtypes
original_label: Lung Small Cell Carcinoma Molecular Subtypes
definition: A header term that refers to the molecular classification of lung small cell carcinoma according to the relative expression of four transcription factors: achaete-scute homolog 1 (ASCL1), neurogenic differentiation factor 1 (NEUROD1), yes-associated protein 1 (YAP1), and POU class 2 homeobox 3 (POU2F3).
A ganglioneuroma that occurs in adults.
A neoplasm that affects the nervous system during childhood.
A rare ganglioneuroma that arises from the choroid.

mondo_label: childhood connective and soft tissue neoplasm
original_label: Childhood Connective and Soft Tissue Neoplasm
definition: A soft tissue or bone neoplasm that occurs during childhood.
A low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma that occurs during childhood.
A teratoma that develops as a primary tumor in an anatomic site other than the testis or ovary.
A testicular teratoma associated with germ cell neoplasia in situ and chromosome 12p amplification.
A term that refers to the classification of kidney carcinomas according to their molecular characteristics.

mondo_label: ovarian sertoli-leydig cell tumor molecular subtypes
original_label: Ovarian Sertoli-Leydig Cell Tumor Molecular Subtypes
definition: A term that refers to the classification of ovarian Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors according to their molecular characteristics.

A benign papillary neoplasm that arises from the cervix or vagina. It mostly occurs in prepubertal girls and rarely in adolescents or young adults. It is characterized by the presence of a fibrovascular core covered by cuboidal or columnar epithelial cells. Squamous metaplasia may be present. Cytologic atypia is absent.
A neoplasm that affects the breast and occurs during childhood.
A neoplasm that affects any part of the digestive system and occurs during childhood.

A subtype of hepatoblastoma characterized by the presence of an epithelial component and absence of mesenchymal elements. It includes hepatoblastoma with pure fetal epithelial differentiation, hepatoblastoma with combined fetal and embryonal epithelial differentiation, macrotrabecular hepatoblastoma, and small cell undifferentiated hepatoblastoma (small cell undifferentiated hepatoblastoma with loss of INI1 nuclear staining should be classified as rhabdoid tumor).
A mixed epithelial and mesenchymal hepatoblastoma characterized by the absence of heterologous elements, muscle, cartilage or osteoid.
A term that refers to the staging of hepatoblastoma, following the rules of the PRETEXT (pre-treatment extent of tumor) system.
A term that refers to the staging of hepatoblastoma according to post-operative findings.
A fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma that occurs during childhood.
A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the epithelial cells of an endocrine organ during childhood.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that involves the tissues of the thorax during childhood.
A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the anatomic structures of the head and neck region and occurs during childhood.
A benign, intermediate, or malignant neoplasm that affects the skin and occurs during childhood.
A rare carcinoma that occurs during childhood.
T/NK-cell lymphoproliferative disorder that is resistant to treatment.
The reemergence of T/NK-cell lymphoproliferative disorder after a period of remission.
T/NK-cell lymphoproliferative disorder that is associated with Epstein-Barr virus.
A neoplasm that occurs during childhood and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.
A neoplasm that arises from the liver and is characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.

A group of aggressive endometrial carcinomas with high-grade histological features. It includes high grade endometrial endometrioid adenocarcinoma, endometrial clear cell adenocarcinoma, endometrial serous adenocarcinoma, and endometrial undifferentiated carcinoma.
Melanoma that affects both the iris and ciliary body.

mondo_label: b acute lymphoblastic leukemia associated with down syndrome
original_label: B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Associated with Down Syndrome
definition: A B-acute lymphoblastic leukemia that occurs in patients with Down syndrome. It usually affects young children, but it can occur in adults as well. It has an unfavorable clinical outcome. Cases of T-acute lymphoblastic leukemia in patients with Down syndrome have not been reported.
Breast carcinoma that is positive for androgen receptors.

mondo_label: b lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma with etv6-runx1-like features
original_label: B Lymphoblastic Leukemia/Lymphoma with ETV6-RUNX1-Like Features
definition: B lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma characterized by a gene-expression profile similar to that of ETV6-RUNX1-positive B lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma, absence of the pathognomonic ETV6-RUNX1 rearrangement, and rearrangements or deletions of ETV6 and IKZF1 genes.

mondo_label: renal cell carcinoma, not otherwise specified
original_label: Renal Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified
definition: A renal cell carcinoma that cannot be classified into one of the established subtypes of renal cell carcinoma.
A benign mesenchymal tumor that arises from the kidney and is composed of mature adipose tissue, thick-walled blood vessels, and epithelioid and spindle smooth muscle cells.
Transformation of plasma cell myeloma to plasma cell leukemia.

mondo_label: papillary urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potential
original_label: Papillary Urothelial Neoplasm of Low Malignant Potential
definition: A papillary neoplasm of the urothelium. The papillary structures exhibit minimal architectural distortion and minimal atypia. Mitoses are infrequent. It usually occurs in the urinary bladder, but it can arise from other sites in the urinary tract. Patients are at an increased risk of developing new papillary lesions. Occasionally, the new lesions are urothelial carcinomas.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma with lymphoepithelioma-like features.
An invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of giant cells.

mondo_label: invasive urothelial carcinoma with glandular differentiation
original_label: Invasive Urothelial Carcinoma with Glandular Differentiation
definition: An invasive urothelial carcinoma that exhibits glandular differentiation.

mondo_label: invasive urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation
original_label: Invasive Urothelial Carcinoma with Squamous Differentiation
definition: An invasive urothelial carcinoma that exhibits squamous differentiation.

mondo_label: invasive urothelial carcinoma with trophoblastic differentiation
original_label: Invasive Urothelial Carcinoma with Trophoblastic Differentiation
definition: An invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of trophoblastic differentiation.
An invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of clear (glycogen-rich) cells.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of lipid laden tumor cells.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by microcysts formation.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by a nested growth pattern.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of malignant cells with plasmacytoid features.
A rare invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of medium to large nests of malignant cells.
Invasive urothelial carcinoma characterized by the presence of a tubular growth pattern.
